name: BIOCARTA_FAS_PATHWAY
full: Receptors in the TNF receptor family are associated with the induction of apoptosis, as well as inflammatory signaling. The Fas receptor (CD95) mediates apoptotic signaling by Fas-ligand expressed on the surface of other cells. The Fas-FasL interaction plays an important role in the immune system and lack of this system leads to autoimmunity, indicating that Fas-mediated apoptosis removes self-reactive lymphocytes. Fas signaling is also involved in immune surveillance to remove transformed cells and virus infected cells. Binding of FAS to oligimerized FasL on another cell activates apoptotic signaling through a cytoplasmic domain termed the death domain that interacts with signaling adaptors including FAF, FADD and DAX to activate the caspase proteolytic cascade. Caspase-8 and caspase-10 are first activated, to then cleave and activate downstream caspases, and a variety of cellular substrates that lead to cell death. Caspases cleave nuclear lamins, causing the nucleus to break down and lose its normal structure and another caspase substrate is DFF, inducing cleavage and degradation of the genome. Other caspase substrates are involved in cytoskeletal structure, cell cycle regulation and signaling pathways. Activation of JNK kinase, activation of Jun, and production of ceramide may also play roles in Fas-mediated apoptosis. Activation of fas-mediated apoptosis is opposed by I-FLICE and FAP. Viruses and tumors may escape immune surveillance in part through suppression of fas-mediated apoptosis using similar mechanisms.

name: BIOCARTA_CARM_ER_PATHWAY
brief: CARM1 and Regulation of the Estrogen Receptor
full: Several forms of post-translational modification regulate protein activities. Recently, protein methylation by CARM1 (coactivator-associated arginine methyltransferase 1) has been observed to play a key role in transcriptional regulation. CARM1 associates with the p160 class of transcriptional coactivators involved in gene activation by steroid hormone family receptors. CARM1 also interacts with CBP/p300 transcriptional coactivators involved in gene activation by a large variety of transcription factors, including steroid hormone receptors and CEBP. One target of CARM1 is the core histones H3 and H4, which are also targets of the histone acetylase activity of CBP/p300 coactivators. Recruitment of CARM1 to the promoter region by binding to coactivators increases histone methylation and makes promoter regions more accessible for transcription. Another target of CARM1 methylation is a coactivator it interacts with, CBP. Methylation of CBP by CARM1 blocks CBP from acting as a coactivator for CREB and redirects the limited CBP pool in the cell to be available for steroid hormone receptors. Other forms of post-translational protein modification such as phosphorylation are reversible in nature, but as of yet a protein demethylase is not known. The methylation activity of CARM1 modulates the activity of specific transcriptional regulators. CARM1 acts as a coactivator for the myogenic transcription factor Mef2c, and is necessary for normal muscle cell differentiation. The estrogen receptor is another transcription factor that uses CARM1 as one of several coactivators, acting synergistically with CBP through the Grip1 member of the p160 family of coactivators. The interaction of estrogen receptor with various ligand-dependent coactivators may produce the tissue selective response of some estrogen receptor ligands like tamoxifen.

Additionally, the HDACs in this cluster are often recruited by co-repressors like NCOR2 to deacetylate histones, leading to transcriptional repression. Conversely, coactivators such as CREBBP and EP300 acetylate histones, promoting transcriptional activation. All in all, this gene cluster demonstrates complex regulatory mechanisms crucial for proper genetic transcription in response to estrogen.

name: KEGG_ERBB_SIGNALING_PATHWAY
full: The ErbB family of receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) couples binding of extracellular growth factor ligands to intracellular signaling pathways regulating diverse biologic responses, including proliferation, differentiation, cell motility, and survival. Ligand binding to the four closely related members of this RTK family -epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR, also known as ErbB-1 or HER1), ErbB-2 (HER2), ErbB-3 (HER3), and ErbB-4 (HER4)-induces the formation of receptor homo- and heterodimers and the activation of the intrinsic kinase domain, resulting in phosphorylation on specific tyrosine residues (pY) within the cytoplasmic tail. Signaling effectors containing binding pockets for pY-containing peptides are recruited to activated receptors and induce the various signaling pathways. The Shc- and/or Grb2-activated mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway is a common target downstream of all ErbB receptors. Similarly, the phosphatidylinositol-3-kinase (PI-3K) pathway is directly or indirectly activated by most ErbBs. Several cytoplasmic docking proteins appear to be recruited by specific ErbB receptors and less exploited by others. These include the adaptors Crk, Nck, the phospholipase C gamma (PLCgamma), the intracellular tyrosine kinase Src, or the Cbl E3 ubiquitin protein ligase.

name: BIOCARTA_LEPTIN_PATHWAY
brief: Reversal of Insulin Resistance by Leptin
full: The insulin resistance of type II diabetes appears to be caused in part by the presence of high levels of lipids in cells such as skeletal muscle where this would not normally be found. The presence of excess lipid stores in skeletal muscle cells interferes with energy metabolism, impairing glucose oxidation and insulin response. Skeletal muscle is one of the primary glucose-consuming tissues, giving it a central role in insulin resistance. The increased risk of diabetes associated with obesity may be caused by increased lipid deposits in skeletal muscle and liver, creating insulin resistance. Leptin is a peptide hormone secreted by adipose tissue that has been associated with many processes. One of the target tissues of leptin is the hypothalamus where it can act to regulate feeding behavior and metabolism. Another leptin target is skeletal muscle. Activation of leptin signaling in skeletal muscle activates the AMP-activated protein kinase (AMP-kinase), known to play a key role in signaling in response to nutrients throughout evolution. AMPK phosphorylates and inactivates the enzyme ACC, acetyl-CoA carboxylase. ACC catalyzes the production of malonyl-CoA from acetyl-CoA. Malonyl-CoA in turn is an inhibitor of the import of fatty acids into mitochondria by carnitine palmitoyl-transferase I for oxidation and energy production. In the presence of leptin, AMPK is activated, ACC is inhibited, and malonyl-CoA levels fall, increasing the oxidation of fatty acids and reducing the lipid content of cells. The reduced lipid content in skeletal muscle allows insulin signaling and glucose consumption to return to their normal levels, reducing insulin resistance.

The gene cluster provided is primarily associated with the regulation of energy metabolism, particularly focusing on the AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) pathway and its interactions with lipid metabolism and energy homeostasis.

### Cluster Identification and Biological Function

The gene cluster centers around the AMPK complex, a critical energy sensor in cells that maintains energy balance. AMPK is a heterotrimeric enzyme composed of a catalytic α subunit (encoded by genes such as **PRKAA1** and **PRKAA2**) and regulatory β and γ subunits (encoded by genes like **PRKAB1**, **PRKAB2**, **PRKAG1**, **PRKAG2**, and **PRKAG3**). The AMPK complex is activated in response to low energy states, such as increased AMP/ATP ratios, and it functions to restore energy balance by activating catabolic pathways and inhibiting anabolic processes.

### Key Genes and Their Functions

Some genes in this cluster, such as **PRKAA1** and **PRKAA2**, encode the catalytic α subunits of AMPK, responsible for the kinase activity of the complex, phosphorylating various downstream targets to regulate energy homeostasis. Other genes, like **PRKAB1** and **PRKAB2**, encode the β subunits, which play a role in stabilizing the AMPK complex and facilitating its activation. Additionally, **PRKAG1**, **PRKAG2**, and **PRKAG3** encode the γ subunits, which contain binding sites for AMP and ATP, thus acting as sensors for the energy status of the cell.

Additionally, **ACACA (Acetyl-CoA carboxylase alpha)** encodes an enzyme that is a key regulator of fatty acid synthesis. AMPK phosphorylates and inhibits ACACA, thereby reducing lipid synthesis when energy is low. **CPT1A (Carnitine palmitoyltransferase 1A)** encodes an enzyme involved in the transport of fatty acids into mitochondria for β-oxidation, and AMPK activation enhances CPT1A activity, promoting fatty acid oxidation. **LEP (Leptin)** and **LEPR (Leptin receptor)** are involved in regulating energy balance by inhibiting hunger, which in turn diminishes fat storage in adipocytes. LEPR is the receptor for leptin, and its interaction with leptin is crucial for the regulation of appetite and energy expenditure.

### Relationships and Regulatory Elements

The AMPK complex acts as a central regulator, integrating signals from various pathways to maintain energy homeostasis. It directly interacts with metabolic enzymes like ACACA and CPT1A to modulate lipid metabolism. The leptin signaling pathway, through LEP and LEPR, provides additional regulatory input, linking energy status to appetite control and energy expenditure.

### Biological Implications

All in all, this gene cluster is vital for maintaining cellular and systemic energy balance. Dysregulation of this cluster can lead to metabolic disorders such as obesity, type 2 diabetes, and cardiovascular diseases. Understanding the interactions within this cluster can provide insights into therapeutic targets for metabolic diseases.

### Gaps in Knowledge

While the roles of individual genes in this cluster are well-characterized, the precise mechanisms of their interactions and regulation in different tissues and under various physiological conditions remain areas of active research. Further studies are needed to elucidate these complex interactions and their implications for metabolic health.

name: KEGG_GLIOMA
full: Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) formation is either de novo (primary GBMs) or due to the progression of a lower grade glioma to a higher grade one through the acquisition of additional mutations (secondary GBMs). In primary GBM, disruption of the p53 pathway often occurs through loss of ARF, or less frequently through amplification of MDM2. Disruption of the RB pathway occurs through loss of INK4A. Amplification and/or mutation of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) is the most frequently detected genetic defect that is associated with primary GBM. In secondary GBM, loss of p53 and activation of the growth-factorreceptor-tyrosine-kinase signalling pathway (such as through overexpression of PDGF/PDGFR ) initiates tumour formation,whereas disruption of the retinoblastoma (RB) pathway contributes to the progression of tumour development. Loss of PTEN has been implicated in both pathways, although it is much more common in the pathogenesis of primary GBM.

name: KEGG_MELANOGENESIS
full: Cutaneous melanin pigment plays a critical role in camouflage, mimicry, social communication, and protection against harmful effects of solar radiation. Melanogenesis is under complex regulatory control by multiple agents. The most important positive regulator of melanogenesis is the MC1 receptor with its ligands melanocortic peptides. MC1R activates the cyclic AMP (cAMP) response-element binding protein (CREB). Increased expression of MITF and its activation by phosphorylation (P) stimulate the transcription of tyrosinase (TYR), tyrosinase-related protein 1 (TYRP1), and dopachrome tautomerase (DCT), which produce melanin. Melanin synthesis takes place within specialized intracellular organelles named melanosomes. Melanin-containing melanosomes then move from the perinuclear region to the dendrite tips and are transferred to keratinocytes by a still not well-characterized mechanism.

The binding of alpha-melanocyte stimulating hormone (alpha-MSH) to MC1R stimulates the synthesis of cAMP, activating MITF and the transcription of genes involved in melanin production, while the agouti protein antagonizes this effect by binding to MC1R and inhibiting cAMP production. name: BIOCARTA_NFKB_PATHWAY
full: Nuclear factor kB (NF-kB) is a nuclear transcription factor that regulates expression of a large number of genes that are critical for the regulation of apoptosis, viral replication, tumorigenesis, inflammation, and various autoimmune diseases. The activation of NF-kB is thought to be part of a stress response as it is activated by a variety of stimuli that include growth factors, cytokines, lymphokines, UV, pharmacological agents, and stress. In its inactive form, NF-kB is sequestered in the cytoplasm, bound by members of the IkB family of inhibitor proteins, which include IkBa, IkBb, IkBg, and IkBe. The various stimuli that activate NF-kB cause phosphorylation of IkB, which is followed by its ubiquitination and subsequent degradation. This results in the exposure of the nuclear localization signals (NLS) on NF-kB subunits and the subsequent translocation of the molecule to the nucleus. In the nucleus, NF-kB binds with a consensus sequence (5'GGGACTTTCC-3') of various genes and thus activates their transcription. IkB proteins are phosphorylated by IkB kinase complex consisting of at least three proteins; IKK1/IKKa, IKK2/IKKb, and IKK3/IKKg. These enzymes phosphorylate IkB leading to its ubiquitination and degradation. Tumor necrosis factor (TNF) which is the best-studied activator binds to its receptor and recruits a protein called TNF receptor death domain (TRADD). TRADD binds to the TNF receptor-associated factor 2 (TRAF-2) that recruits NF-kB-inducible kinase (NIK). Both IKK1 and IKK2 have canonical sequences that can be phosphorylated by the MAP kinase NIK/MEKK1 and both kinases can independently phosphorylate IkBa or IkBb. TRAF-2 also interacts with A20, a zinc finger protein whose expression is induced by agents that activate NF-kB. A20 functions to block TRAF2-mediated NF-kB activation. A20 also inhibits TNF and IL-1 induced activation of NF-kB suggesting that it may act as a general inhibitor of NF-kB activation.

Additionally, the NF-κB pathway is tightly regulated by a balance of activating and inhibitory signals. Key regulatory elements include the IKK complex (CHUK, IKBKB, IKBKG) and inhibitors like NFKBIA and TNFAIP3. The pathway involves a complex network of interactions, with adaptor proteins like MYD88, TRADD, and FADD linking receptors to downstream kinases and transcription factors. Feedback mechanisms, such as the induction of TNFAIP3, help to prevent excessive inflammation.

All in all, this gene cluster represents a critical component of the immune response, with intricate regulatory mechanisms ensuring balanced activation and inhibition of NF-κB signaling. Dysregulation of the NF-κB pathway is implicated in various diseases, including chronic inflammatory conditions, autoimmune diseases, and cancer. Understanding the interactions and regulatory mechanisms within this gene cluster is crucial for developing therapeutic strategies targeting NF-κB signaling in disease contexts.

name: BIOCARTA_BLYMPHOCYTE_PATHWAY
full: B cells must communicate with their environment to participate in the immune system as the source of antigen-specific immunoglobulins. Cell surface proteins on B cells receive signals from the exterior, adhere to other cells, and transmit signals to other cells. Antigen recognized by a B cell's immunoglobulin is presented in MHC Class II to T cells during B cell activation. Cell surface immunoglobulins are a key to B cell function, assisting in the response of B cells to specific antigen recognized by that cell's immunoglobulin. CD54 (ICAM-1) is an adhesion molecule involved in the binding of B cells to other cell types and LFA-1 is an integrin adhesion protein with two subunits that binds to ICAM. CD35 and CD21 are receptors for complement factors that stimulate the B cell response when complement is activated. CD80 and CD40 bind to T cell proteins (CD28 and CD40L, respectively) to provide costimulatory signals in the B cell-T cell interaction required for B cell activation. CD45 is a protein tyrosine phosphatase that regulates activation of B cells and T cells through dephosphorylation of signaling factors. CD32 is a receptor for IgG Fc, and is also called FcgammaRII. The number of proteins on the surface of B cell proteins indicates the complexity of regulation of B cell activation.

name: BIOCARTA_ASBCELL_PATHWAY
full: A key part of the immune system is the production of immunoglobulins (antibodies) by B cells to bind and inactivate specific foreign antigens. The body produces B cells with a wide range of antigen specificities in the immunoglobulin B cell receptor, one antigen specificity per cell. When the B cell receptor immunoglobulin binds antigen, that cell is activated to proliferate and create plasma cells secreting immunoglobulins to bind that specific antigen. B cell activation also creates memory cells with the same antigen specificity that do not actively secrete immunoglobulin but provide for rapid future immune responses to the same antigen. B cells are not activated by antigen on their own, but require interaction with helper CD4+ T cells to become activated and proliferate. The B cell first expresses immunoglobulin on the cell surface as the B cell receptor. If the B cell receptor immunoglobulin binds specific antigen, then the cell internalizes the antigen and presents it to T cells in MHC II, where it is recognized by the T cell receptor. In addition to the interaction between the T cell receptor and the B cell MHC-antigen, T cell interaction with the B cell involves additional positive and negative regulatory signals. CD40 interaction with CD40L and CD28 interaction with CD80 provide positive costimulatory signals that stimulate B cell activation and proliferation. T cell receptor activation induces expression of molecules like the CD40 ligand that modulate the B cell-T cell interaction. The CD40-CD40L interaction induces cytokine production and expression of other genes and alters the fate of the B cell involved in the interaction. If the interaction between CD40 and CD40L is prolonged, the B cell can be induced to become a memory cell rather than a plasma cell. Fas ligand binding to Fas between B and T cells may negatively modulate B cell activation, inducing apoptosis that limits B cell proliferation and activation. Cytokines like IL-2, IL-4 and IL-10 also play an important role in B cell activation.

name: BIOCARTA_CYTOKINE_PATHWAY
full: Several different cell types coordinate their efforts as part of the immune system, including B cells, T cells, macrophages, neutrophils, basophils and eosinophils. Each of these cell types has a distinct role in the immune system, and communicates with other immune cells using secreted factors called cytokines, including interleukins, TNF, and the interferons. Macrophages phagocytose foreign bodies and are antigen-presenting cells, using cytokines to stimulate specific antigen dependent responses by B and T cells and non-specific responses by other cell types. T cells secrete a variety of factors to coordinate and stimulate immune responses to specific antigen, such as the role of helper T cells in B cell activation in response to antigen. The proliferation and activation of eosinophils, neutrophils and basophils respond to cytokines as well. Cytokine communication is often local, within a tissue or between cells in close proximity. Each of the cytokines is secreted by one set of cells and provokes a response in another target set of cells, often including the cell that secretes the cytokine. Some cytokines, like IL-1, interferons and TNF, stimulate a broad inflammatory response in response to infection or injury. Other cytokines have more specific functions such the following examples. IL-2 stimulates the proliferation and activation of B and T cells. IL-4 plays a role in the differentiation of Th2 cells, in allergic responses, and in the switching of antibody types. IL-5 stimulates the production and maturation of eosinophils during inflammation. IL-8 is a chemokine, a chemotactic factor that attracts neutrophils, basophils and T cells to sites of inflammation. IL-12 and IL-18 are involved in helper T cell differentiation. IL-10 apparently acts to repress secretion of proinflammatory cytokines. The complex interplay of these different cytokine functions with immune cells is essential for correct immune function.

The gene cluster responsible for the innate immune response serves as the first line of defense against invading microorganisms, activating within a few hours of infection. Some genes in this cluster lead to the activation of macrophages and neutrophils by microbial components such as lipopolysaccharide (LPS). Macrophages and neutrophils respond by secreting cytokines such as TNF-alpha, IL-1, IL-6, and IL-8, which further activate the innate and adaptive immune responses mediated by T cells and antibodies. 

Other genes, like those associated with Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4), recognize bacterial LPS and play a critical role in activating the innate immune response. An important transcription factor in this process, NF-kappaB, is initially inhibited by I-kappaB in the absence of LPS. However, upon LPS stimulation, I-kappaB is phosphorylated, ubiquitinated, and ultimately degraded, liberating NF-kappaB to translocate into the nucleus and activate genes that contain NF-kappaB binding sites. This activation is facilitated by IRAK-1 and the adapter protein MyD88, with subsequent activation of NIK and phosphorylation-induced degradation of I-kappaB.

Additionally, the activation of NF-kappaB by LPS is a transient response, quickly attenuated by the induction of I-kappaB and feedback inhibition from cytokines IL-1 and IL-4, mediated by transcription factor STAT3. This transient nature is crucial for rapidly activating and then attenuating the immune response, preventing potential problems like septic shock caused by an over-exuberant inflammatory response.

All in all, this gene cluster orchestrates a complex but regulated innate immune response, ensuring a rapid but controlled reaction to pathogenic threats while preventing excessive inflammation and collateral tissue damage.

name: BIOCARTA_RARRXR_PATHWAY
brief: Nuclear receptors coordinate the activities of chromatin remodeling complexes and coactivators to facilitate initiation of transcription in carcinoma cells
full: RXR and RAR are nuclear receptors that bind either all trans retinoic (tRA) or 9cis retinoic acid (9cisRA). In the absence of ligand corepressors with histone deacetylase activity are bound to the RAR/RXR hetrodimer and suppress transcription. Once they bind retinoic acid a conformational change in the receptors cause the dissociation of the corepressors and the binding of coactivators with histone acetylase activity (1). Following ligand binding by the hetrodimer the receptors and proteins in the basal transcription machinery (like TBP and TAF135) are degraded by the proteasome (2).

Other genes, like KAT2B, function as histone acetyltransferases, facilitating transcriptional activation and playing roles in chromatin remodeling and various cellular processes. Additionally, TBP and GTF2A1 are critical components of the transcription initiation complex, with TBP binding to the TATA box and GTF2A1 stabilizing this interaction to facilitate the recruitment of other transcription factors. RXRA and RARA form a functional heterodimer central to retinoic acid signaling, regulating gene expression patterns crucial for development and homeostasis. All in all, this gene cluster is pivotal in processes such as development, differentiation, and metabolism, with dysregulation potentially leading to pathologies like cancer, metabolic disorders, and developmental abnormalities. Understanding the interactions and regulatory mechanisms within this cluster is crucial for developing therapeutic strategies targeting nuclear receptor signaling pathways.
ZulGene: The gene cluster for the retinoic acid receptor (RAR) is part of the steroid hormone receptor gene family. It is activated by the vitamin A derivative retinoic acid (RA) and is instrumental in various developmental processes. Some genes in this cluster include the RAR alpha form, which is present in most adult tissues and is crucial for the development of the central nervous system. Other genes include the RAR beta form, which is located in the lung, skin, and male germ cells, and is vital for the development of the lung and male germ cells. Additionally, RAR functions as a ligand-activated transcription factor. Upon binding RA, it forms a heterodimer with the retinoid X receptor (RXR), another member of the steroid hormone receptor family. This RAR/RXR heterodimer binds to DNA at a retinoic acid response element (RARE) and recruits coactivators that possess histone acetyltransferase activity, necessary for transcriptional activation. Corepressors also bind to the RAR/RXR heterodimer, but upon RA binding, they are released, and coactivators are recruited. Coactivators, containing histone acetyltransferase and Bromo domains, are crucial for transcriptional activation and may aid in chromatin remodeling. Corepressors have a repression domain interacting with the RAR/RXR heterodimer and are released upon RA binding. Coactivators then recruit corepressors to the promoter region of RA-responsive genes. These corepressors have a deacetylase domain that might be involved in chromatin remodeling. The binding of coactivators and corepressors to the RAR/RXR heterodimer depends on the DNA sequence of the RARE, which can be in various forms such as direct repeats and inverted repeats with specific spacing. The RAR/RXR heterodimer can also bind to negative response elements (NREs) in the promoters of RA-responsive genes, which have a lower affinity than RAREs. These NREs can be formatted as direct or inverted repeats and have the unique ability to repress transcription in the presence of RA, yet activate it in its absence. All in all, this gene cluster, through its ability to bind to different response elements, enables RA to regulate a diverse array of genes.

name: BIOCARTA_MTA3_PATHWAY
brief: Downregulated of MTA-3 in ER-negative Breast Tumors
full: Approximately 30% of breast carcinomas lack ER expression. Presumably, these breast cancers become estrogen independent through genetic alterations that bypass the requirement for ER-dependent stimulation of cell proliferation. As such estrogen receptor is a key regulator of proliferation and differentiation in mammary epithelia and represents a crucial prognostic indicator and therapeutic target in breast cancer. Mechanistically, estrogen receptor induces changes in gene expression through direct gene activation of a number of genes (cathepsin D, HSP27 (heat shock protein 27,000 kDa, aldolase A, dehydrogenase, alpha-tubulin, and glyceraldehyde-3-phosphat, Pdzk1, Greb ets) and also through the biological functions of target loci. The product of human MTA3 has been identified as an estrogen-dependent component of the Mi-2/NuRD transcriptional corepressor in breast epithelial cells and demonstrate that MTA3 constitutes a key component of an estrogen-dependent pathway regulating growth and differentiation. The absence of estrogen receptor or of MTA3 leads to aberrant expression of the transcriptional repressor Snail, a master regulator of epithelial to mesenchymal transitions. Aberrant Snail expression results in loss of expression of the cell adhesion molecule E-cadherin, an event associated with changes in epithelial architecture and invasive growth. MTA3 is the mechanistic link between estrogen receptor status and invasive growth of breast cancers.

All in all, this gene cluster highlights the interplay between transcriptional regulation, cytoskeletal dynamics, and metabolic pathways in cancer biology. The presence of EMT-related genes (SNAI1, SNAI2, CDH1) alongside those involved in hormone response (ESR1, GREB1) and stress response (HSPB1, HSPB2) underscores the complexity of cancer progression and metastasis. name: KEGG_CELL_ADHESION_MOLECULES_CAMS
full: Cell adhesion molecules are (glyco)proteins expressed on the cell surface and play a critical role in a wide array of biologic processes that include hemostasis, the immune response, inflammation, embryogenesis, and development of neuronal tissue. There are four main groups: the integrin family, the immunoglobulin superfamily, selectins, and cadherins. Membrane proteins that mediate immune cellcell interactions fall into different categories, namely those involved in antigen recognition, costimulation and cellular adhesion. Furthermore cell-cell adhesions are important for brain morphology and highly coordinated brain functions such as memory and learning. During early development of the nervous system, neurons elongate their axons towards their targets and establish and maintain synapses through formation of cell-cell adhesions. Cell-cell adhesions also underpin axon-axon contacts and link neurons with supporting schwann cells and oligodendrocytes.

- **Cell Adhesion and Immune Response:** Cadherins and integrins work together to maintain tissue architecture and facilitate immune cell migration. Integrins also interact with immunoglobulin superfamily members to mediate leukocyte adhesion and transmigration.

- **Tight Junctions and Barrier Function:** Claudins form tight junction strands that regulate paracellular permeability, crucial for maintaining tissue homeostasis and barrier function against pathogens.

- **Immune Modulation:** MHC molecules present antigens to T-cells, while checkpoint molecules modulate T-cell responses, balancing immune activation and tolerance.

### Regulatory Elements and Patterns:

- **Gene Expression Regulation:** Many of these genes are regulated by cytokines and growth factors, which modulate their expression in response to inflammation, infection, or tissue injury.

- **Epigenetic Modifications:** Histone modifications and DNA methylation patterns can influence the expression of these genes, impacting immune responses and cell adhesion properties.

### Biological Implications:

- **Disease Associations:** Dysregulation of these genes is implicated in various diseases, including cancer, autoimmune disorders, and infectious diseases. For example, altered expression of MHC molecules and checkpoint proteins can lead to immune evasion by tumors.

- **Therapeutic Targets:** Checkpoint inhibitors targeting PD-1/PD-L1 and CTLA-4 pathways are already in use for cancer immunotherapy, highlighting the clinical significance of this gene cluster.

All in all, this gene cluster encompasses a diverse array of genes integral to cell adhesion, immune function, and intercellular communication, with significant implications for health and disease. Further research is needed to fully elucidate the complex interactions and regulatory mechanisms governing these genes.

name: BIOCARTA_EPHA4_PATHWAY
brief: Eph Kinases and ephrins support platelet aggregation
full: Eph kinases are a family of receptor tyrosine kinases with an extracellular domain that binds their ligand, the ephrins, and an intracellular kinase domain. The ephrins are also expressed on the cell surface, so that interaction between Eph kinases and ephrins occurs at the interface between neighboring cells. Binding of ephrins to Eph kinases stimulates signaling in both directions across the interface between cells, in both the receptor expressing and the ligand expressing cells. Eph kinases and ephrins are involved in several biological processes, and their role in neuronal development has been extensively examined. Both Eph kinases (EphA4 and EphB1) and ephrins (ephrinB1) are expressed on platelets, suggesting activation of eph kinases by ephrins may play a role in clotting when platelets are brought into close proximity in the developing clot. Platelet activation progresses in stages with an early stage that is stimulated by soluble factors like ADP acting through GPCRs and is reversible and later stages with stronger interaction between platelets that may require interact between Eph kinases and ephrins. One of the molecular targets of signaling by Eph kinases and ephrins is the actin cytoskeleton, which also plays a role in platelet activation. Clustering Eph kinases or ephrins in platelets stimulated cytoskeletal changes as well as other markers of platelet activation during clotting such as secretion of alpha-granules to release clotting factors. Clustering ephrins together activated Rap1b, a ras gene family member that may regulate integrins. Platelet activation caused Eph kinases to bind to src family members Fyn and Lyn and also with the cell adhesion molecule L1. Failure of the ephrins/Eph kinase pathway to function normally in platelets may result in loosely associated platelets and improper clot formation. Eph kinases and ephrins are also expressed on the vascular wall by endothelial cells, suggesting that signaling by these proteins may also play a role in the interaction of platelets with the vascular wall and clot formation in the vasculature.

ZulGene: The gene cluster involved in thrombus formation at the site of vascular injury is a complex system that includes platelets, the coagulation cascade, and endothelial interactions. Some genes in this cluster are responsible for the interaction of platelets with the damaged vessel wall, which leads to the exposure of subendothelial matrix proteins and stimulates the binding of von Willebrand factor (vWF) to the platelet glycoprotein Ib-IX-V complex. Other genes facilitate the activation of integrin alpha IIb beta 3 (GPIIb-IIIa) by vWF binding, which is essential for platelet aggregation. Additionally, vWF binding induces fibrinogen binding to alpha IIb beta 3, crucial for stable platelet aggregation. Furthermore, vWF binding enhances phospholipase A2 activation, freeing arachidonic acid from membrane phospholipids, with subsequent conversion of arachidonic acid to thromboxane A2 (TXA2) by thromboxane synthase, amplifying further thromboxane A2 production. The additional binding of fibrinogen, supported by activated GPIb-IX-V, strengthens platelet aggregation and initiates further phospholipase A2 activation, which is vital not only for further TXA2 formation but also for generating other platelet agonists like ADP and serotonin. This pathway also activates the protein kinase C pathway, influencing phosphorylation of proteins such as myosin light chains, which regulate platelet shape change and aggregation. Finally, thrombin binding to its receptor on the platelet surface activates the protease-activated receptor PAR4 and the glycoprotein Ib-IX-V complex, contributing to platelet activation. All in all, this gene cluster intricately regulates the thrombus formation process, ensuring effective platelet activation and aggregation during vascular injury.

name: KEGG_T_CELL_RECEPTOR_SIGNALING_PATHWAY
full: Activation of T lymphocytes is a key event for an efficient response of the immune system. It requires the involvement of the T-cell receptor (TCR) as well as costimulatory molecules such as CD28. Engagement of these receptors through the interaction with a foreign antigen associated with major histocompatibility complex molecules and CD28 counter-receptors B7.1/B7.2, respectively, results in a series of signaling cascades. These cascades comprise an array of protein-tyrosine kinases, phosphatases, GTP-binding proteins and adaptor proteins that regulate generic and specialised functions, leading to T-cell proliferation, cytokine production and differentiation into effector cells.

The p21-activated kinase (PAK), a downstream target of the small GTPases Rac and Cdc42, is activated by the guanine nucleotide exchange factor vav, and this activation by Rac and Cdc42 is also crucial for T cell activation.

All in all, this gene cluster orchestrates a comprehensive network of signals and pathways vital for the successful activation of T cells.

name: KEGG_BASE_EXCISION_REPAIR
full: Base excision repair (BER) is the predominant DNA damage repair pathway for the processing of small base lesions, derived from oxidation and alkylation damages. BER is normally defined as DNA repair initiated by lesion-specific DNA glycosylases and completed by either of the two sub-pathways: short-patch BER where only one nucleotide is replaced and long-patch BER where 2-13 nucleotides are replaced. Each sub-pathway of BER relies on the formation of protein complexes that assemble at the site of the DNA lesion and facilitate repair in a coordinated fashion. This process of complex formation appears to provide an increase in specificity and efficiency to the BER pathway, thereby facilitating the maintenance of genome integrity by preventing the accumulation of highly toxic repair intermediates.
GPT:
The gene cluster provided is primarily involved in the Base Excision Repair (BER) pathway, a critical cellular mechanism for repairing small base lesions in DNA that result from oxidation, alkylation, deamination, or spontaneous loss of a base. This pathway is essential for maintaining genomic stability and preventing mutations that could lead to cancer and other diseases.

Some genes in this cluster encode DNA glycosylases, such as NEIL1, NEIL2, and NEIL3, which recognize and remove oxidized bases, initiating the BER process. OGG1 specifically excises 8-oxoguanine, a common oxidative lesion, while MUTYH removes adenines misincorporated opposite 8-oxoguanine. UNG and SMUG1 are involved in uracil removal, with UNG excising uracil from DNA arising from cytosine deamination. TDG excises thymine and uracil from G:T and G:U mismatches, respectively, and MBD4 recognizes and removes T from G:T mismatches.

Other genes include endonucleases and lyases such as APEX1 and APEX2, which are apurinic/apyrimidinic (AP) endonucleases that cleave the DNA backbone at abasic sites created by glycosylases. NTHL1 functions similarly to NEIL glycosylases, with lyase activity to cleave DNA at damaged sites. DNA polymerases like POLB (DNA Polymerase Beta) fill in the single nucleotide gap left after lesion removal, while POLL is another polymerase involved in gap-filling during BER. The subunits of DNA polymerase epsilon (POLE, POLE2, POLE3, POLE4) and delta (POLD1, POLD2, POLD3, POLD4) are also involved in DNA repair and replication. Ligases such as LIG1 and LIG3 seal the nicks in the DNA backbone after repair synthesis.

Additionally, accessory proteins like XRCC1 act as a scaffold protein, coordinating the activities of various BER enzymes, and PCNA (Proliferating Cell Nuclear Antigen) enhances the processivity of DNA polymerases during repair. FEN1 removes flap structures that can form during long-patch BER. The PARP family, including PARP1, PARP2, PARP3, and PARP4, consists of poly(ADP-ribose) polymerases that detect DNA strand breaks and signal for repair, recruiting other repair proteins to the site of damage. HMGB1 facilitates DNA bending and repair complex assembly, while HMGB1P1 and HMGB1P40 are pseudogenes related to HMGB1, with unclear roles in BER.

The BER pathway is highly coordinated, with glycosylases recognizing specific lesions and initiating repair, followed by endonucleases and lyases processing the DNA, and polymerases and ligases completing the repair. XRCC1 serves as a central hub, interacting with multiple proteins to ensure efficient repair. PARP proteins play a crucial role in detecting DNA damage and recruiting repair machinery, highlighting their importance in the initial response to DNA damage.

All in all, this gene cluster represents a comprehensive network of proteins that work together to maintain DNA integrity, highlighting the complexity and importance of the BER pathway in cellular homeostasis. Defects in BER genes can lead to the accumulation of DNA damage, contributing to carcinogenesis and other age-related diseases. Understanding the interactions and regulation of these genes is crucial for developing therapeutic strategies targeting DNA repair pathways in cancer treatment.
ZulGene: The gene cluster Base Excision Repair (BER) represents the major pathway for rectifying small DNA lesions, specifically alkylated or oxidized bases. Some genes in this cluster encode DNA glycosylases that initiate the repair process by recognizing damaged bases, cleaving the bond between the base and the deoxyribose phosphate, and releasing both the damaged base and an apurinic/apyrimidinic (AP) site. Other genes contribute to processing the AP site, which is incised by an AP endonuclease, followed by filling the resulting single-stranded DNA (ss-DNA) gap with a DNA polymerase and sealing it with a DNA ligase. Additionally, DNA glycosylases in the BER pathway are categorized into monofunctional DNA glycosylases, which remove only damaged bases and are found in bacteria and some lower eukaryotes, and bifunctional DNA glycosylases, which remove both damaged bases and the deoxyribose phosphate (dRP) group and are present in higher eukaryotes. These bifunctional enzymes contain an N-terminal glycosylase domain and a C-terminal AP lyase domain; the glycosylase domain releases the damaged base, and the AP lyase domain cleaves the DNA strand at the AP site, producing a 3'-phospho-alpha, beta-unsaturated aldehyde (PUA) residue and a 5'-phosphate. The removal of the dRP group is carried out by the 5'-phosphodiesterase activity of pol beta or the 3'-phosphodiesterase activity of APE1, and DNA ligase I or III (or potentially IV) completes the sealing of the DNA strand. All in all, the gene cluster includes enzymes like nth-like DNA glycosylase 1 (NEIL1) and NEIL2, identified as bifunctional DNA glycosylases distinct from E. coli Fpg and Nei proteins. These enzymes, which share similar structural domains (a glycosylase domain and an AP lyase domain), play a crucial role in the repair of oxidative DNA damage and are localized in the nucleus.

name: BIOCARTA_P53_PATHWAY

It may do this in multiple ways from holding the cell at a checkpoint until repairs can be made to causing the cell to enter apoptosis if the damage cannot be repaired. The critical role of p53 is evidenced by the fact that it is mutated in a very large fraction of tumors from nearly all sources.

name: BIOCARTA_CK1_PATHWAY
brief: Regulation of ck1/cdk5 by type 1 glutamate receptors
full: Cdk5 is a cyclin dependent protein kinase involved in dopaminergic signaling in the neostriatal region of the brain. The role of cdk5 in dopamine responses occurs through phosphorylation of DARPP-32. Caseine kinase 1 (CK1) also regulates DARPP-32 phosphorylation and dopamine signaling. The phosphorylation of DARPP-32 by cdk5 reduced dopamine signaling. Depending on its phosphorylation state, DARPP-32 inhibits either protein phosphatase 1 (PP1) or PKA. The role of mGLUR1 in this process is supported by the induction of cdk5 and CK1 activity by the mGLUR1 agonist DHPG and the subsequent phosphorylation of DARPP-32 associated with DHPG treatment of nigrostriatal neurons. CK-1 and Ckd5 inhibitors block the DHPG induced DARPP-32 phosphorylation. Dopamine exerts a positive signal that increases dopamine response by reversing phosphorylation of DARPP-32 at threonine-75. Dopamine initiates this pathway through activation of the D1 dopamine receptor, a Gs coupled GPCR, elevating cAMP and activating PKA. PKA activates protein phosphatase 2A (PP2A) which dephosphorylates DARPP-32 and increases dopamine responsiveness. This also removes the inhibition of PKA by DARPP-32, forming a positive feedback loop for further DARPP-32 inactivation by PKA. Activation of the D2 dopamine receptor has the opposite effect, shifting the DARPP-32 population toward the threonine-75 phosphorylated form.

name: BIOCARTA_IGF1R_PATHWAY
brief: Multiple antiapoptotic pathways from IGF-1R signaling lead to BAD phosphorylation
full: IGF-1R, the type 1 receptor for insulin-like growth factor, mediates cell survival and growth in response to its ligands IGF-1 and IGF-2. This tyrosine kinase receptor is widely expressed in many cell types and is a key mediator of growth. Overexpression or activation of IGF-1R may be involved in the proliferation of transformed cells, making inhibition of IGF-1R signaling a strategy for the development of cancer drugs. IGF-1R activates three signaling pathways that converge to phosphorylate BAD protein and block apoptosis. The first pathway activated by IGF-1R stimulates PI3-kinase and the AKT pathway to phosphorylate BAD and block apoptosis. A second pathway activated by IGF-1R involves ras mediated activation of the map kinase pathway to block apoptosis. A third pathway involves interaction of raf with mitochondria in response to IGF-1R activation. The convergence of these pathways to block apoptosis may enhance the IGF-1R response.

Other genes, such as **PIK3R1** and **PIK3CA**, encode components of the PI3K complex, which is involved in the PI3K/AKT signaling pathway, often interacting with the MAPK/ERK pathway to regulate cell survival and growth. **AKT1** is a serine/threonine kinase that is a central node in the PI3K/AKT pathway, promoting cell survival and growth. **IGF1R**, the insulin-like growth factor 1 receptor, is a receptor tyrosine kinase that activates both the MAPK/ERK and PI3K/AKT pathways upon ligand binding. **SOS1** is a guanine nucleotide exchange factor that facilitates the activation of RAS proteins, linking receptor tyrosine kinases to the MAPK/ERK pathway. **GRB2** and **SHC1** are adaptor proteins that link activated receptor tyrosine kinases to SOS1, facilitating RAS activation. **RPS6KA1 (RSK1)** is a downstream effector of ERK1/2, involved in the regulation of protein synthesis and cell growth. **PRKACG, PRKACB, PRKAR1A, PRKAR1B, PRKAR2A, PRKAR2B** encode components of the protein kinase A (PKA) complex, which can intersect with the MAPK/ERK pathway, influencing cellular responses to hormonal signals. **BAD** is a pro-apoptotic member of the Bcl-2 family, regulated by phosphorylation through the PI3K/AKT pathway, linking survival signals to apoptotic pathways. **ADCY1**, adenylate cyclase 1, is involved in the production of cAMP, which can modulate PKA activity and intersect with MAPK/ERK signaling. **YWHAH** encodes 14-3-3 eta, a protein that interacts with phosphorylated proteins, including those in the MAPK/ERK pathway, to regulate their activity and localization.

Additionally, the MAPK/ERK pathway is initiated by growth factors binding to receptor tyrosine kinases like IGF1R, leading to the activation of RAS (HRAS), which then activates RAF1. RAF1 phosphorylates and activates MEK1 (MAP2K1), which in turn activates ERK1/2 (MAPK3/1). The PI3K/AKT pathway, involving PIK3R1, PIK3CA, and AKT1, often works in parallel with the MAPK/ERK pathway, providing a survival signal that can counteract apoptotic signals. Cross-talk between these pathways is facilitated by shared components and regulatory proteins, such as BAD and 14-3-3 proteins (YWHAH).

All in all, this gene cluster represents a complex network of signaling pathways that are crucial for normal cellular function and are often hijacked in disease states. Dysregulation of the MAPK/ERK and PI3K/AKT pathways is a hallmark of many cancers, as these pathways control critical aspects of cell proliferation and survival. Understanding the interactions and regulatory mechanisms within this gene cluster can provide insights into therapeutic targets for cancer and other diseases involving aberrant cell signaling. Further research is needed to fully elucidate the intricate regulatory mechanisms and potential therapeutic interventions.

name: KEGG_PROGESTERONE_MEDIATED_OOCYTE_MATURATION
full: Xenopus oocytes are naturally arrested at G2 of meiosis I. Exposure to either insulin/IGF-1 or the steroid hormone progesterone breaks this arrest and induces resumption of the two meiotic division cycles and maturation of the oocyte into a mature, fertilizable egg. This process is termed oocyte maturation. The transition is accompanied by an increase in maturation promoting factor (MPF or Cdc2/cyclin B) which precedes germinal vesicle breakdown (GVBD). Most reports point towards the Mos-MEK1-ERK2 pathway and the polo-like kinase/CDC25 pathway as responsible for the activation of MPF in meiosis, most likely triggered by a decrease in cAMP.

All in all, this gene cluster comprises a tightly regulated network that ensures accurate cell division and genome integrity through diverse regulatory mechanisms and checkpoints.

name: BIOCARTA_LAIR_PATHWAY
brief: Cells and Molecules involved in local acute inflammatory response
full: Inflammation has several distinct components, including the localized response at the site of tissue injury or infection. Tissue injury stimulates the release of inflammatory signaling molecules such as bradykinin. Bacterial infection stimulates an immune response in several ways. Bacteria that are phagocytosed can activate macrophages, causing the release of inflammatory cytokines such as IL-1, TNF, and IL-6. Bacteria can also activate the complement cascade through either the antibody-mediated pathway (classical pathway) or the alternative complement pathway. In extravascular tissues, cells that respond to infection or injury include macrophages and mast cells. Macrophages and other immune cells secrete chemokines that recruit leukocytes from the circulation to the site of inflammation. Mast cells release histamine, prostaglandins, and leukotrienes that act as chemokines, increase vascular permeability, and act on the vascular endothelium to increase tissue recruitment of leukocytes. Chemokines can recruit leukocytes or lymphocytes out of the blood stream into tissues and make blood vessels more permeable. Leukocytes are activated by inflammatory signals to express adhesion molecules that cause them to interact with the vascular endothelium, penetrate the endothelial wall and migrate into the extracellular space of tissues. The combined response of immune cells and signaling molecules at the site of inflammation induces swelling, activation of immune cells, and clearance of potential infectious agents. Chronic inflammation can however also lead to tissue damage in conditions such as arthritis, in which anti-inflammatory drugs act on various steps in inflammation to prevent disease.

Further research is needed to elucidate the precise regulatory mechanisms and interactions within this cluster.

This interaction, as well as the interaction of Mac-1 with its endothelial ligands, is inhibited by the serum protein alpha 1-antichymotrypsin. All in all, this gene cluster coordinates critical pathways in inflammation and immune response mechanisms.

name: BIOCARTA_RHO_PATHWAY
full: RhoA is a small G-protein in the Rho family that regulates cell morphology via actin cytoskeleton reorganization in response to extracellular signals. The majority of RhoA activations is due to disruption of intramolecular autoinhibitory interactions. Changes in cytoskeletal structure and other aspects of cell structure are involved in cell morphology. RhoA is activated by GEF factors, and repressed by GAPs. GEFs are guanine nucleotide exchange factors. GAPs are GTPase-activating proteins. The RhoGAP ARHGAP1 also acts as a GAP for Rac and CDC42. Active RhoA increases the stability of actin-based structures such as stress fibers and focal adhesions. Several different factors downstream of RhoA act on cytoskeletal structures to affect stability of these structures. Rock1 provides a direct link from RhoA to cell morphology through phosphorylation of the myosin light chain. Rock1 also phosphorylates and activates LIM kinase, which phosphorylates cofilin. Cofilin stimulates actin depolymerization and changes in cell structure, and phosphorylation of cofilin by LIM kinase represses this activity. According to Nimnual et al. Rho activity is reduced as a result of Rac-induced redox-dependent inhibition. Related Disease: Non-syndromic deafness appears to be the result of amino acid substitutions in the 52-amino acid C-terminal end of Dia 1. This modification creates a constituatively active Dia 1 protein. A mutation in the RhoGAP Oligophrenin-1 is thought to contribute to a form of mental retardation due to loss of Rho inhibition in neuronal development.

### Key Genes and Their Functions:

1. **ARHGEF5, ARHGEF11, ARHGEF1**: These genes encode Rho guanine nucleotide exchange factors (GEFs), which activate Rho GTPases by facilitating the exchange of GDP for GTP. This activation is crucial for initiating downstream signaling pathways that regulate actin cytoskeleton organization.

2. **ARHGAP1, ARHGAP6, ARHGAP5, ARHGAP4**: These genes encode Rho GTPase-activating proteins (GAPs), which inactivate Rho GTPases by stimulating their intrinsic GTPase activity, converting GTP to GDP. This inactivation is essential for turning off Rho GTPase signaling and ensuring proper cellular responses.

Other genes in the cluster include:

3. **RHOA**: A member of the Rho family of GTPases, RHOA is a central regulator of the actin cytoskeleton, influencing cell shape, motility, and division.

4. **ROCK1**: Rho-associated coiled-coil containing protein kinase 1 (ROCK1) is a downstream effector of RHOA, mediating various cellular processes such as contraction, adhesion, and motility through phosphorylation of target proteins.

5. **MYL2**: Encodes myosin light chain 2, which is involved in muscle contraction and is regulated by phosphorylation, a process influenced by Rho/ROCK signaling.

6. **BAIAP2 (IRSp53)**: This gene encodes a protein that links Rho GTPase signaling to actin cytoskeleton remodeling, playing a role in filopodia formation and cell motility.

7. **OPHN1**: Encodes oligophrenin 1, a RhoGAP involved in synaptic function and neuronal development, highlighting the role of Rho signaling in the nervous system.

8. **PPP1R12B**: Encodes a regulatory subunit of protein phosphatase 1, which is involved in the dephosphorylation of myosin light chains, thus influencing muscle contraction and cell motility.

9. **TLN1 (Talin 1)**: A cytoskeletal protein that links integrins to the actin cytoskeleton, playing a critical role in cell adhesion and migration.

10. **PFN1 (Profilin 1)**: Binds actin monomers and regulates actin polymerization, essential for cell movement and structure.

11. **GSN (Gelsolin)**: An actin-binding protein that severs and caps actin filaments, regulating actin dynamics.

12. **DIAPH1**: A formin protein that nucleates actin filaments, promoting their elongation and playing a role in cytokinesis and cell polarity.

13. **PIP5K1A, PIP5K1B**: Encode phosphatidylinositol-4-phosphate 5-kinases, which produce phosphatidylinositol (4,5)-bisphosphate, a lipid that regulates actin dynamics and is involved in signal transduction.

14. **VCL (Vinculin)**: A cytoskeletal protein involved in cell-cell and cell-matrix junctions, crucial for maintaining cell integrity and transmitting mechanical signals.

15. **LIMK1**: A kinase that phosphorylates and inactivates cofilin, a protein that disassembles actin filaments, thus regulating actin dynamics.

Additionally, the interplay between GEFs and GAPs in this cluster highlights the dynamic regulation of Rho GTPase activity, ensuring precise control over actin cytoskeleton remodeling. ROCK1, as a downstream effector of RHOA, links Rho GTPase activation to changes in cell contractility and motility. The presence of actin-binding proteins like PFN1, GSN, and DIAPH1 underscores the cluster's role in actin filament dynamics, essential for cellular processes such as migration and division.

### Biological Implications:

- Dysregulation of Rho GTPase signaling is implicated in various diseases, including cancer metastasis, cardiovascular diseases, and neurological disorders.
- Understanding the interactions within this gene cluster can provide insights into therapeutic targets for modulating cell movement and invasion in pathological conditions.

All in all, this gene cluster represents a critical network for regulating the actin cytoskeleton and cellular dynamics, with significant implications for health and disease.
ZulGene: The gene cluster known as the Rho family of GTPases, which includes RhoA, Rac1, and Cdc42, functions as molecular switches that alternate between an inactive GDP-bound state and an active GTP-bound state. Some genes in this cluster are activated by guanine nucleotide exchange factors (GEFs), which facilitate the release of bound GDP and the binding of GTP, thus transitioning the molecules into their active form. Other genes are influenced by GTPase-activating proteins (GAPs), which enhance the intrinsic GTPase activity of Rho-GTPases; this action encourages the conversion from the active GTP-bound state back to the inactive GDP-bound state. Additionally, guanine nucleotide dissociation inhibitors (GDIs) bind to Rho-GTPases, maintaining them in the inactive state in the cytosol by attaching to the isoprenyl group of Rho-GTPases and inhibiting interaction with other regulators and effectors. Guanine nucleotide exchange factors (GEFs) are the only known regulators of Rho-GTPases and are classified into four subfamilies based on sequence homology: the Dbl-homology (DH) domain family, the Vav family, the Map kinase kinase family, and the PSD-95/discs large/ZO-1 (PDZ) domain family. GEFs are activated by upstream signals and are regulated through mechanisms like the release of inhibitory interactions, protein-protein interactions, and phosphorylation, allowing them to facilitate GDP release and GTP binding on Rho-GTPases. Activated Rho-GTPases engage with various downstream targets to convey signals leading to multiple cellular responses. Specific effectors link Rho-GTPases to certain cellular actions. For instance, RhoA promotes the formation of stress fibers and focal adhesions via the Rho-associated coiled-coil containing protein kinase 1 (ROCK1) and p160ROCK. Rac1 is involved in lamellopodial extension through the activation of the kinase Pak1, which phosphorylates the regulatory light chain of myosin II. The function of Cdc42 in cellular responses is less clear, but it is believed to regulate the formation of filopodia through phosphorylation of the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP) and the Arp2/3 complex. All in all, this gene cluster plays a crucial role in regulating cellular dynamics and responses through intricate regulatory mechanisms and interactions.

name: BIOCARTA_SODD_PATHWAY
full: The tumor necrosis factor (TNF) receptor superfamily contains several members with homologous cytoplasmic domains known as death domains (DD). The intracellular DD are important in initiating apoptosis and other signaling pathways following ligand binding by the receptors.1 In the absence of ligand, DD-containing receptors are maintained in an inactive state. TNF RI contains a cytoplasmic DD required for signaling pathways associated with apoptosis and NF-kB activation.2,3 Jiang et al.4 identified a widely expressed 60 kDa protein, named SODD (silencer of death domains), associated with the DD of TNF RI and DR3. Overexpression of SODD suppresses TNF-induced cell death and NF-kB activation demonstrating its role as a negative regulatory protein for these signaling pathways. TNF-induced receptor trimerization aggregates the DD of TNF RI and recruits the adapter protein TRADD.3,5 This in turn promotes the recruitment of the DD-containing cytoplasmic proteins FADD, TRAF2 and RIP to form an active TNF RI signaling complex (Figure 1A).6-9 In contrast, SODD acts as a silencer of TNF RI signaling and does not interact with TRADD, FADD, or RIP (Figure 1B).4 It is associated with the DD of TNF RI and maintains TNF RI in an inactive, monomeric state. TNF-induced aggregation of TNF RI promotes the disruption of the SODD-TNF RI complex. SODD does not interact with the DD of other TNF receptor superfamily members such as Fas, DR4, DR5, or TNF RII. SODD association with TNF RI may represent a general model for the prevention of spontaneous TNF signaling by other DD-containing receptors.

Inhibitors of apoptosis such as BIRC3 and BAG4 are also part of this cluster. BIRC3 (baculoviral IAP repeat-containing protein 3), also known as cIAP2, inhibits caspases and promotes cell survival by ubiquitinating RIPK1. BAG4 (BCL2-associated athanogene 4), also known as SODD, negatively regulates TNFR1 signaling by preventing spontaneous receptor activation.

Caspases, particularly CASP8, are crucial in this cluster. CASP8 (caspase 8) is a crucial initiator caspase in the extrinsic apoptosis pathway. It is activated upon recruitment to the death-inducing signaling complex (DISC) formed by FADD and TRADD, leading to the execution of apoptosis.

The balance between pro-apoptotic and pro-survival signals in this cluster is tightly regulated. The ubiquitination of RIPK1 by TRAF2 and BIRC3 is a critical control point, determining whether the cell undergoes apoptosis or survives. Dysregulation of this gene cluster can lead to various diseases, including cancer, autoimmune disorders, and chronic inflammatory conditions. Overactive TNF signaling is implicated in inflammatory diseases, while impaired apoptosis can contribute to cancer progression. All in all, this gene cluster orchestrates a complex network of signals that determine cell fate, balancing apoptosis and survival, with significant implications for health and disease.
ZulGene: The gene cluster known as the TNF receptor superfamily consists of cell-surface receptors that induce apoptosis upon binding with their respective ligands. Some genes in this cluster include the Fas receptor (also referred to as APO1, CD95, and TNFRSF6), which is activated by the Fas ligand (also known as APO1L, CD95L, and TNFSF6) to trigger apoptosis in various cell types. Other genes in this cluster participate in a signaling cascade where the binding of Fas ligand to the Fas receptor causes the receptor to aggregate and recruit the Fas-associated death domain (FADD). Cytochrome c then interacts with Apaf-1 to activate caspase-9, initiating a caspase cascade that leads to apoptosis. Bcl-2 and Bcl-xL mitigate this mitochondrial pathway by preventing the release of cytochrome c. All in all, this gene cluster orchestrates a complex pathway that controls the induction of apoptosis through both extracellular and mitochondrial signals.

name: KEGG_RNA_DEGRADATION
full: The correct processing, quality control and turnover of cellular RNA molecules are critical to many aspects in the expression of genetic information. In eukaryotes, two major pathways of mRNA decay exist and both pathways are initiated by poly(A) shortening of the mRNA. In the 5' to 3' pathway, this is followed by decapping which then permits the 5' to 3' exonucleolytic degradation of transcripts. In the 3' to 5' pathway, the exosome, a large multisubunit complex, plays a key role. The exosome exists in archaeal cells, too. In bacteria, endoribonuclease E, a key enzyme involved in RNA decay and processing, organizes a protein complex called degradosome. RNase E or R interacts with the phosphate-dependent exoribonuclease polynucleotide phosphorylase, DEAD-box helicases, and additional factors in the RNA-degrading complex.
GPT:
The gene cluster provided is primarily associated with RNA processing and degradation, involving components of the exosome complex, the Lsm complex, the CCR4-NOT complex, and other related factors. Some genes in this cluster play crucial roles in RNA metabolism, including RNA decay, surveillance, and processing, which are essential for maintaining cellular RNA homeostasis.

### Key Components and Functions:

1. **Exosome Complex (EXOSC1-10, DIS3, RRP6/EXOSC10):**
   - The exosome is a multi-protein complex essential for the degradation of various RNA species. It is involved in the 3' to 5' exonucleolytic decay of RNA and is crucial for RNA quality control and processing. **DIS3** and **EXOSC10 (RRP6)** are catalytic subunits providing exonuclease activity.

2. **Lsm Complex (LSM1-8):**
   - The Lsm proteins form a heptameric ring that binds to RNA, playing a role in mRNA decay and splicing. Lsm1-7 is involved in mRNA decapping and decay, while Lsm2-8 is associated with U6 snRNA in splicing.

3. **CCR4-NOT Complex (CNOT1-10):**
   - This complex is a major regulator of mRNA deadenylation, a critical step in mRNA decay. It also influences transcription and translation. **CNOT1** serves as a scaffold, while other subunits like **CNOT6** and **CNOT7** have deadenylase activity.

4. **Decapping Enzymes (DCP1A, DCP1B, DCP2, DCPS):**
   - These enzymes remove the 5' cap from mRNA, a key step in mRNA decay. **DCP2** is the catalytic subunit, while **DCP1A** and **DCP1B** act as regulatory factors.

5. **XRN1 and XRN2:**
   - These are 5' to 3' exonucleases involved in degrading uncapped RNA. **XRN1** functions in the cytoplasm, while **XRN2** is nuclear.

6. **SKI Complex (SKIC2, SKIC3, SKIC8):**
   - Works with the exosome to degrade RNA. It is involved in the cytoplasmic 3' to 5' decay pathway.

7. **PARN:**
   - A poly(A)-specific ribonuclease involved in mRNA deadenylation, working in concert with the CCR4-NOT complex.

8. **DDX6 and EDC3/EDC4:**
   - DDX6 is an RNA helicase involved in mRNA decapping and decay. EDC3 and EDC4 are enhancers of decapping.

9. **PAPOLA, PAPOLB, PAPOLG:**
   - These are poly(A) polymerases involved in the polyadenylation of mRNA, a process that can influence mRNA stability and translation.

10. **HSPA9 and HSPD1:**
    - These are heat shock proteins involved in protein folding and stress responses, indirectly affecting RNA metabolism by maintaining protein homeostasis.

### Relationships and Regulatory Elements:

- The interplay between the exosome, Lsm, and CCR4-NOT complexes is crucial for the regulation of mRNA stability and decay.
- Decapping and deadenylation are tightly coordinated processes that precede RNA decay, with the CCR4-NOT complex often initiating deadenylation.
- The exosome and SKI complex collaborate for efficient RNA degradation, particularly in the cytoplasm.

### Biological Implications:

- Proper functioning of these complexes is vital for gene expression regulation, cellular stress responses, and the prevention of aberrant RNA accumulation.
- Dysregulation can lead to diseases, including cancer and neurodegenerative disorders, due to the accumulation of faulty or excess RNA.

All in all, this gene cluster highlights the complexity and interconnectivity of RNA processing pathways, emphasizing the importance of coordinated regulation for cellular homeostasis. Further research is needed to fully elucidate the specific interactions and regulatory mechanisms within this cluster.

Another is a previously unidentified, putative serine/threonine kinase, KIS, which might be regulated by stathmin or, more likely, be part of the kinases controlling its phosphorylation state. Finally, two proteins, CC1 and CC2, predicted to form alpha-helices participating in coiled-coil interacting structures. It has been also suggest that the action of antimicrotubule drugs can be affected by stathmin in at least two ways: (a) altered drug binding; and (b) growth arrest at the G2 to M boundary. Mutant p53 breast cancers exhibiting high levels of stathmin may be resistant to antimicrotubule agents.

name: BIOCARTA_BARRESTIN_PATHWAY
full: Role of -arrestins in the desensitization, sequestration and intracellular trafficking of GPCRs. Homologous desensitization of GPCRs (1) results from the binding of -arrestins (-arr) to agonist -occupied receptors following phosphorylation of the receptor by GRKs. -arrestin binding sterically precludes coupling between the receptor and heterotrimeric G proteins, leading to termination of signaling by G proteins effectors. Receptor-bound -arrestins also act as adapter proteins, binding to components of the clathrin endocytic machinery including clathrin, 2-adaptin (AP-2). Receptor sequestration (2) reflects the dynamin (Dyn)-dependent endocytosis of GPCRs via clathrin-coated pits. Once internalized, GPCRs exhibit two distinct patterns of -arrestin interaction. `Class A' GPCRs, for example the 2 adrenergic receptor, rapidly dissociate from -arrestin upon internalization. These receptors are trafficked to an acidified endosomal compartment, wherein the ligand is dissociated and the receptor dephosphorylated by a GPCR-specific protein phosphatase PP2A isoform, and are subsequently recycled to the plasma membrane (3). `Class B' receptors, for example the angiotensin II AT1a receptor, form stable receptor--arrestin complexes. These receptors accumulate in endocytic vesicles and are either targeted for degradation or slowly recycled to the membrane via as yet poorly defined routes.

name: BIOCARTA_AKAP95_PATHWAY
brief: AKAP95 role in mitosis and chromosome dynamics
full: The chromatin packaging of the genome is dynamic, changing with the cell cycle and with transcriptional regulation. During mitosis, chromatin is condensed for segregation of chromosomes, while for transcription chromatin is more open. The nuclear matrix, or scaffold, is a protein network in the nucleus providing structure and regulating chromatin condensation. Regulated interactions of matrix proteins with each other, DNA and other factors in different phases of the cell cycle alter the structure and function of chromatin. AKAP95 (A-kinase anchoring protein) is a nuclear matrix associated protein that also binds DNA and different proteins during different phases of the cell cycle. The interaction of AKAP95 with DNA and proteins alters the condensation and transcription of chromatin. A specific domain of AKAP95 regulates its interaction with the nuclear matrix and another regulates its association with DNA. One key protein that AKAP95 interacts with is the cAMP-dependent protein kinase, PKA. AKAP95 binds to PKA through a PKA RII regulatory subunit, an interaction that requires PKA phosphorylation by Cdk1. PKA activity and cAMP are reduced during entry into mitosis, but PKA recruited by AKAP95 to condensed chromosomes is essential to maintain the condensed state. Another protein recruited by AKAP95 is Eg7, a 150 kD protein recruited during mitotic chromatin condensation. Eg7 is a part of a multiprotein condensin complex, recruiting another key component of mitotic chromatin condensation. Modification of the core histones through phosphorylation regulates chromatin condensation. Histone H3 interacts with the condensin complex, and is phosphorylated during mitosis. Histone H3 phosphorylation by Aurora-2 induces chromatin condensation, and dephosphorylation by PP1 promotes chromatin decondensation for reentry into interphase. AKAP95 may play a role during the regulation of chromatin structure for transcription during interphase as well. The interaction of AKAP95 with the p68 RNA helicase recruits this enzyme to the nuclear matrix during interphase. Other nuclear RNA helicases interact with transcription factors and cofactors, suggesting that the p68 RNA helicase also may regulate interactions of transcription complexes.

They are involved in regulating cell division, differentiation, and development. **MAP2K1 (MEK1)** and **MAP2K2 (MEK2)** are upstream kinases that activate MAPK3 and MAPK1 through phosphorylation, serving as key regulatory nodes in the MAPK/ERK signaling cascade. **RAF1** encodes a serine/threonine kinase that acts upstream of MEK1/2, playing a pivotal role in the activation of the MAPK/ERK pathway and is involved in cell growth and survival. **HRAS**, a member of the RAS family of GTPases, is involved in transmitting signals from growth factor receptors to the MAPK/ERK pathway, with mutations associated with various cancers.

Other genes, such as **GNAS**, encode the G-protein alpha subunit involved in GPCR signaling, playing a role in activating adenylate cyclase and leading to the production of cAMP, a secondary messenger. **GRK2** is a G-protein-coupled receptor kinase involved in the desensitization of GPCRs, regulating their activity and ensuring proper signal termination. **ADCY1** encodes adenylate cyclase 1, an enzyme that converts ATP to cAMP, a crucial secondary messenger in many signaling pathways. **PLCB1** is involved in the hydrolysis of phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate, generating inositol trisphosphate and diacylglycerol, important for calcium signaling and activation of protein kinase C. **ARRB1** is involved in the regulation and desensitization of GPCRs, playing a role in receptor internalization and signaling. **FGR** and **HCK** encode Src family tyrosine kinases involved in signaling pathways that regulate immune responses, cell growth, and differentiation. **KCNA1, KCNA2, KCNA3** encode voltage-gated potassium channels, important for maintaining the membrane potential and regulating neuronal excitability. **DNM1** is involved in endocytosis and membrane trafficking, playing a role in synaptic vesicle recycling.

Additionally, the MAPK/ERK pathway is tightly regulated by a series of phosphorylation events, with RAF1, MEK1/2, and ERK1/2 forming a sequential activation cascade. GPCR signaling is modulated by GRK2 and ARRB1, which ensure proper receptor desensitization and internalization. Cross-talk between the MAPK/ERK pathway and GPCR signaling is facilitated by shared components such as GNAS and ADCY1, linking receptor activation to downstream signaling events.

All in all, this gene cluster represents a complex network of signaling pathways essential for maintaining cellular homeostasis and responding to external signals. Dysregulation of the MAPK/ERK pathway is implicated in various cancers, making components like HRAS, RAF1, and MEK1/2 potential targets for therapeutic intervention. The involvement of GNAS and ADCY1 in cAMP production highlights their role in metabolic regulation and potential implications in metabolic disorders. The presence of voltage-gated potassium channels (KCNA1, KCNA2, KCNA3) suggests a role in neuronal signaling and potential implications in neurological disorders. Further research is needed to fully elucidate the interactions and regulatory mechanisms within this cluster.
ZulGene: The gene cluster known as the G-protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) superfamily encompasses receptors that respond to a wide array of extracellular stimuli, including hormones, neurotransmitters, light, odorants, and pheromones. Some genes in this cluster are responsible for the coupling of these receptors to intracellular heterotrimeric G proteins, composed of alpha, beta, and gamma subunits. The alpha subunit can interact with and regulate downstream effectors such as adenylyl cyclase, phospholipase C, and ion channels. Other genes focus on the roles of the beta gamma subunits, which are capable of interacting with and activating the MAP kinase cascade. Additionally, the family of four proteins known as beta-arrestins binds to agonist-activated GPCRs, blocking further receptor-G-protein coupling. They also couple receptors to the activation of the MAP kinase cascade and participate in receptor internalization and downregulation. The second messenger pathways and the MAP kinase cascade are crucial for regulating cellular proliferation and differentiation. The regulation of many GPCR activities involves receptor kinases (GRKs), which phosphorylate the receptor to create a binding site for beta-arrestins. All in all, this gene cluster provides a rapid mechanism for controlling the activity of GPCRs through the regulation by GRKs and beta-arrestins.

name: KEGG_STEROID_HORMONE_BIOSYNTHESIS
full: Steroid hormones derived from cholesterol are a class of biologically active compounds in vertebrates. The cholesterol side-chain cleavage enzyme CYP11A1 catalyzes conversion of cholesterol, a C27 compound, to the first C21 steroid, pregnenolone, which is converted by a bifunctional enzyme complex to the gestagen hormone, progesterone. Pregnenolone and progesterone are the starting materials for the three groups of steroids: C21 steroids of glucocorticoids and mineralocorticoids, C19 steroids of androgens, and C18 steroids of estrogens. (i) Progesterone is converted by hydroxylations at carbons 21 and 11 to corticosterone, which is further modified by hydroxylation and oxydoreduction at carbon 18 to yield aldosterone, a mineralcorticoid. Cortisol, the main glucocorticoid, is formed from 17alpha-hydroxyprogesterone with 11-deoxycortisol as an intermediate. (ii) Male hormone testosterone is formed from pregnenolone by two pathways, delta5 pathway via dehydroepiandrosterone and delta4 pathway via androstenedione. The enzyme CYP17A1 is responsible for the 17,20 lyase and 17alpha-hydroxylase activities in respective pathways. (iii) Female hormones estrone and estradiol are formed from testosterone and 4-androstene-3,17-dione by oxidative removal of the C19 methyl group and subsequent aromatization of ring A. In addition to these three groups, recent studies show that there is another group, termed neurosteroids, synthesized in the brain rather than the peripheral endocrine gland.
